headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Stacy. Good morning and welcome, everyone, to Capital One's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. As usual, we are webcasting live over the Internet. To access the call on the Internet, please log on to Capital One's website at ca
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Stacy. Good morning and welcome, everyone, to Capital One's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. As usual, we are webcasting live over the Internet. To access the call on the Internet, please log on to Capital One's website at capitalone.com and follow the links from there. 
In addition to the press release and financials, we have included a presentation summarizing our third quarter 2010 results. With me today are Mr. Richard Fairbank, Capital One's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Gary Perlin, Capital One's Chief Financial Officer and Principal Accounting Officer. Rich and Gary will walk you through this presentation. To access a copy of the presentation and the press release, please go to the Capital One's website, click on Investors, then click on Quarterly Earnings Release.
Please note that this presentation may contain forward-looking statements. Information regarding Capital One's financial performance and any forward-looking statements contained in today's discussion and the material speak only as of the particular date or dates indicated in the material. Capital One does not undertake any obligation to update or revise any of this information, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
Numerous factors could cause our actual results to differ materially from those described in forward-looking statements. For more information on these factors, please see the section titled Forward-Looking Information in the earnings release presentation and the Risk Factor section in our annual and quarterly reports, which are accessible at the Capital One website and filed with the SEC.  
And now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Perlin. Gary?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning to everyone listening on the call. Let me go straight to the income statement on Slide 3. Capital One earned $803 million or $1.76 per share in the second quarter, up 32% from the prior quarter. This bottom line improvement
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning to everyone listening on the call. Let me go straight to the income statement on Slide 3. Capital One earned $803 million or $1.76 per share in the second quarter, up 32% from the prior quarter. This bottom line improvement was driven by a 6% increase in pre-provision earnings as well as a $189 million after-tax improvement in discontinued operations. 
Revenue increased in the quarter by $112 million or nearly 3% despite a 1.5% decrease in average loans.  Net interest margin improved 12 basis points in the quarter, benefiting from the impact of improving credit and finance charge reversals as well as from lower funding costs. The majority of the improvement in revenue came from noninterest income, as the $16 million of continuing operations rep and warranty expense in the quarter was $79 million less than the prior quarter. I'll provide additional color on our rep and warranty position in a moment.
Noninterest expenses were down slightly in the linked quarter as a modest increase in marketing expense was more than offset by an improvement in operating expenses, which, you may recall, were inflated last quarter due to several nonrecurring items. Finally, underlying credit performance continues to improve across our businesses with charge-offs down almost $200 million in the quarter. Overall provision expense, however, was up $144 million as the third quarter allowance release of $624 million were some $382 million lower than the prior quarter.
Turning to Slide 4. I'll discuss our rep and warranty reserve. There have been several questions about our rep and warranty reserves, and so I'd like to spend some time this morning discussing how we establish reserves and how we think about our risks. First, let me explain how we have approach our rep and warranty reserves conceptually. In the aggregate, we have set up reserves with respect to our entire rep and warranty risk for all probable and reasonably estimable contingencies. We include both litigation and non-litigation rep and warranty risks within this reserves. 
To give you more transparency into how we determine probable and reasonably estimable risk, I'll walk you through how we approach reserves with respect to three groups of counterparties. First, the GSEs [government-sponsored enterprises] as purchasers of whole loans. Second, securitization trust wrapped by monoline bond insurers. And three, everything else. 
To the GSEs as purchasers of whole loans, we have established reserves that represent our best estimate of our total future liability, what I'll call lifetime reserves. We have established these reserves based on: our lifetime loss estimates for the underlying loans we sold to the GSEs; and our history of dealing with the GSEs, in terms of the percentage of loans that turn into repurchase request; and the percentage of those requests that ultimately lead to actual repurchases. To the GSEs, the process involves a loan-by-loan negotiation that has developed a rhythm over time that lends itself nicely to predictive models. That's not to say there's no risk to our GSE reserve number. The GSEs could change their approach to repurchase requests, and our estimate of the lifetime losses for the loans at issue are, of course, subject to macroeconomic trends, such as unemployment and home prices. But we think the risk of large movements within the GSE reserve is relatively small. 
To the monoline bond insurers, we have established lifetime reserves for transactions currently subject to repurchase requests. These reserves are based on our lifetime loss estimates of the loans in the securitization trust at issue and our anticipated buyback rate. Although we've establish lifetime reserves for this group, there is more uncertainty here than with the GSEs. This is because the monoline requests will largely be resolved through the judicial system. If the insurers have been active in suing both mortgage loan originators and our MBS securitizers after making what we believe are aggressive repurchase request. In addition, bond insurers may pursue repurchases in the future with respect to transactions not currently subject to repurchase requests and for which we have not established lifetime reserves. Their decision about whether to make repurchase requests on those transactions may depend on whether they expect to take losses.
Before we discuss the third category on Slide 4, the sold to unwrapped securitizations and other whole loan sales, or the everything-else category, it's helpful to understand why monoline insurers have been very active in the rep and warranty space as compared to investors within the non-wrapped deals. Securitization trust wrapped with bond insurance often allowed the bond insurer to act independently of the investors. Bond insurers typically have indemnity agreements directly with both the mortgage originators and the securitizers, and they often have super majority rights within the trust documentation that allow them to force trustees to pursue mortgage buybacks. 
By contrast, investors in non-wrapped securitizations often face a number of legal and procedural hurdles before they can force the deal trustees to pursue mortgage buybacks, including the need to coordinate with 25% to 50% of the securities holders. Indeed, often 25% to 50% of each affected tranche and to an indemnify the trustee for any litigation. We have faced very little repurchase activity from public securitizations not wrapped by bond insurers in the past year. 
We estimate that about half of our everything-else category consists of securitizations not wrapped with bond insurance. And because we have seen virtually no repurchase activity from this group in the past year, a very small amount of our reserve is held against this category. But to be clear, we have established reserves for all probable and reasonably estimable risk with respect to this everything-else category. If we begin to expect increased repurchase or litigation activity in this category and if those risks become probable and reasonably estimable, we would reevaluate our reserves to reflect those risks. 
You should also know that, except for a limited amount of Chevy Chase originated loans, our subsidiaries did not act as securitizers of mortgage loans. Instead, they largely sold whole mortgage loans to others who securitize them. So the legal risks around the securitization process itself are relatively small for us.
Now for the numbers. Our reserve in the third quarter stayed roughly flat at $836 million, down from $853 million. Our rep and warranty loss expense, including settlements for the quarter, was $16 million to $17 million. As you can see on Slide 4, between 2005 and 2008, our subsidiaries sold to non-affiliates about $111 billion in original principal balance mortgage loans. 
Our second quarter estimate of $122 billion in originations included some sales to our affiliates, which, of course, do not create rep and warranty risk. So $111 billion is the number we should start with. Of this amount, about $29 billion was sold either to GSEs or into wrapped securitizations, $11 billion to the GSEs, $13 billion into wrapped deals currently making repurchase requests and another $5 billion to wrapped deals where the bond insurers are not currently active in seeking repurchase requests.  In this last category, we believe bond insurers are not making repurchase requests because, in general, they're not experiencing significant insurance losses. 
Almost all of our $836 million reserve is based on risks, and the $24 billion in loans sold to GSEs and active wrapped securitizations and almost all of the repurchase request we have received in the past year are from these two groups. You'll also see from the slide a sizable build of the rep and warranty reserve in the second quarter when we almost doubled the reserve as we moved to capture expected lifetime losses in our reserving methodology. The build, based on lifetime loss estimates last quarter, helps explain why you're not seeing a large build this quarter. 
Because we don't service most of the loans we sold to others, we don't have complete visibility into where the remaining $82 billion of loans landed. But we know from proprietary databases that about half landed in unwrapped public securitizations. As we discussed, we have seen virtually no repurchase activity from this $82 billion, either from the identified unwrapped securitizations or the remainder, which explains why only a small amount of our reserves is held against those originations. 
Now let's quickly move to the balance sheet on Slide 5. End-of-period loans were down less than 1% in the quarter, the slowest pace of contraction since the second quarter of 2009. Excluding the impact of our runoff portfolios, total loan balances would've been up modestly in the quarter. Our Domestic Card portfolio was down approximately $800 million or 1.4%, driven largely by $750 million in continued runoff from our Installment Loan portfolio. The Commercial Banking loan portfolio remained essentially flat in the quarter at $29.5 billion as we're seeing some signs of stabilization in CRE [commercial real estate], particularly in the New York metro area.
Consumer Banking assets were stable in the quarter as $442 million of Auto Finance growth largely offset $559 million of expected runoff in our Home Loans business. We grew our Securities portfolio by approximately $500 million in the quarter, with the bulk of growth in agency MBS and floating rate ABS [asset-backed securities]. The portfolio performed in line with the broader market ,and our unrealized gain position is now $833 million, down $97 million in the second quarter level. 
In the liability side. We continue to leverage our banking platforms to take advantage of strong demand for deposits, with total deposits up $1.9 billion in the quarter. We drove down our cost of funds by another five basis points in the quarter to 1.64% by replacing over $2 billion of term wholesale funding with cheaper deposits. We continue to expect securitized assets to end 2010 at around $27 billion, which represents a 44% decline from year-end 2009. And our loan-to-deposit ratio is now 1.06, the lowest point in our company's history.
As we turn to Slide 6, I'll discuss the allowance. The company's charge-off rate fell 54 basis points in the quarter to 4.82% while delinquencies fell 10 basis points to 3.71%. The continued improvement in credit drove a $624 million release in the allowance, which now stands at $6.2 billion or 4.89% of loans. $569 million of the reduction in the allowance was in the Card business, driven by lower-than-anticipated losses, declining delinquencies and a modest decline in loan balances. Given the underlying credit trends we are experiencing, it's not unreasonable to assume that our corporate allowance levels will likely continue to decline. 
Let me now finish my section by covering capital on Slide 7. Strong earnings in the quarter led to a 50-basis-point increase to our tangible common equity, the tangible managed assets ratio, which now stands at 6.6%. It's worth noting that this level is higher than our TCE [tangible common equity] ratio prior to the implementation of FAS 167. And taking into account the allowance, our total risk-bearing capacity is now at 10%, well above the year-end 2009 level even as credit performance has improved materially. 
Strong earnings also bolstered our Tier 1 risk-based capital [RBC] ratio by 130 basis points. While on-boarding of risk-weighted assets due to consolidation of securitizations, which existed as of January 1, was due to begin regulatory phase-in in the third quarter, we effectively spread this effect over the first three quarters of this year by paying down our securitization liability. However, because the balance of the phase-in of risk-weighted assets will occur in the first quarter of 2011, we've modeled our expected capital trajectory for 2011 on Slide 8. 
We modeled expected future capital levels using analyst consensus earnings and reasonable balance sheet assumptions, consistent with current expectations, to provide an illustrative expected capital trajectory. It's important to note that we are neither endorsing consensus estimates nor providing capital guidance, and we do not intend to provide updates to this model in future periods. However, we thought it would be helpful to illustrate the expected near-term capital trajectory. 
In the upper left hand corner, you can see that our TCE experienced a temporary dip in the first quarter of 2010 as we built $4.3 billion of allowance associated with the implementation of FAS 167. Strong earnings and a declining intangible assets over subsequent quarters had helped drive that ratio above where it was at the end of last year. Because TCE only includes GAAP equity in the numerator and total assets in the denominator, it remains unaffected by changes in regulatory definitions. It's future trajectory will only be impacted by underlying business performance and balance sheet growth. 
And both the Tier 1 Common and Tier 1 Risk-Based Capital graphs, you can see how those ratios fell along with TCE in the first quarter of 2010 due to the allowance build upon GAAP consolidation. However, unlike TCE, those ratios will likely experience one more dip in the first quarter of 2011 as the result of two factors that affect regulatory ratio definitions: first, the remaining risk-weighted asset phase-in will affect the denominator; and second, we will likely see an increase in the amount of DTA [deferred tax assets] disallowed in the numerator of regulatory capital ratios. This disallowance is cyclical, owing to a two-year carryback limitation that now coincides with the period of recessionary losses. As loss levels abate, the extinguishment of this allowed DTA accelerates our regulatory capital accretion, since allowance release will flow to regulatory capital on a pretax basis. 
Recent announcements from the Basel committee will also impact future regulatory capital definitions and requirements. But because Capital One is not materially impacted by two of the largest changes to the regulatory capital calculations, namely the exclusion of mortgage-servicing rights and capital and an increased need to hold capital related to trading books, our expected regulatory capital trajectory after the first quarter of 2011 is fundamentally upward and we expect to reach the 7% Basel III Tier 1 common minimum, plus based conservation buffer level in 2011, using the fully phased-in Basel III definitions. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Rich to discuss the performance of our businesses. Rich?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin with margins on Slide 9. Net interest margin improved in the quarter. Modest funding cost improvements continued, and asset yields benefited from a higher day count in the third quarter. Revenue margin
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'll begin with margins on Slide 9. Net interest margin improved in the quarter. Modest funding cost improvements continued, and asset yields benefited from a higher day count in the third quarter. Revenue margin increased as the result of the lower reps and warranty reserve build that Gary discussed as well as higher Domestic Card revenue margins. 
Domestic Card revenue margin increased to about 16.8% for the third quarter. Favorable credit drove most of the increase. Improving credit means that more of our finance charge and fee billings will be collectible. This enabled us to recognize revenue for a greater portion of third quarter billings. In other words, we had lower revenue suppression in the third quarter than the second quarter. Improving credit and collectibility also allowed us to recognize revenue for prior finance charge and fee billings that had been suppressed from revenue in earlier quarters. In other words, third quarter revenues included a release of prior suppressions, consistent with improving results. 
Purchase volume in our Domestic Card business increased, due in part to seasonal pattern. The purchase volumes were also up strongly from the prior year quarter. Strong purchase volumes drove higher interchange revenue in the quarter. These positive forces were partially offset by the expected decline in late fee revenues with the mid-quarter implementation of the new CARD Act rules and by modest attrition of higher-margin loans. 
We've been indicating that we expect quarterly domestic revenue margin in the Card business to decline to a more normal historical level of around 15% by the end of this year, as the revenue impacts of the CARD Act play out. CARD Act revenue impacts have played out largely as we expected. And with the full quarter effect of reduced late fees next quarter, we expect CARD Act revenue impacts will be fully absorbed into revenue margin. 
But the revenue margin has remained higher than 15%, driven by two factors: revenue benefits from improving credit have proved more persistent than we had expected and weak demand has resulted in fewer-than-expected new balances at promotional rates. We expect both of these factors to normalize over time, causing revenue margin to decline from its current level. 
Looking forward, Domestic Card revenue margin trends will be determined predominantly by market pricing, the competitive environment and credit results. Purchase volume and loan growth will also impact revenue margins, whether growth comes through increasing origination, portfolio acquisition or partnerships, like the expected addition of Kohl's. We continue to expect the Domestic Card revenue margin will remain at a level consistent with very healthy overall returns for the Card business. 
Slide 10 shows credit results for our Consumer businesses. Charge-off in delinquencies were stable or improving across our Consumer businesses, with the exception of an expected seasonal uptick in Auto delinquencies and charge-offs. Auto Finance credit remains exceptionally strong, with significant improvements year-over-year. This is largely driven by the high quality of recent vintages which now represents over 2/3 of our auto portfolio. 
The overall economic recovery remains modest and fragile, which is consistent with the assumptions we've been applying in our provisioning and underwriting for some time now. Recent labor market statistics show continuing stagnation. We continue to see risk in the housing market as well, as the shadow inventory of homes and foreclosure over severely delinquent mortgages remained very high. And the foreclosure crisis is disrupting housing market, which is likely to extend the time it takes to begin a clear recovery. 
Our credit results have continued to improve even as the pace of economic recovery has faltered a bit over the last couple of quarters. Some of the improvement is due to the benefit of portfolio turnover, which as I noted a moment ago, is particularly important in our Auto business. Some of the improvement is due to consumer deleveraging, although one shouldn't overstate this effect. Most of the actual deleveraging, especially in Card, is due to charge-offs. That said, new borrowing is still very low by historical standards. And that's likely to help improve credit quality, albeit at the expense of growth. 
Much of the improvement in credit, particularly in Card is due to the nature of the labor market problems. Simply put, people who have been unemployed for a long time, we think, has already charged off. Therefore, we'd expect that long-term unemployment, which is unusually high right now would have a smaller impact on credit performance than shorter-term unemployment. In fact, shorter-term unemployment has started to fall in the last couple of quarters and seems to be more correlated to our delinquencies than overall unemployment.
Slide 11 shows credit results for our Commercial Banking business. Commercial Banking credit metrics remain elevated and somewhat uneven but are showing signs of improvement for the second quarter in a row. Nonperforming asset rates improved, except for a slight uptick in our middle market C&I [Commercial & Industrial] business. In addition to the improvement in nonperforming asset rates, we experienced a second consecutive quarter-over-quarter decline in the dollar amount of criticized loans, reflecting stabilization across our Commercial Banking businesses. 
During the quarter, we saw some continuing improvement in the CRE market. For the second quarter in a row, leasing activity increased and vacancies declined in New York, where we have our largest CRE exposure. Traditional CRE investors continue to reenter the market, providing needed liquidity. And sponsors are investing new equity into troubled transactions, which has allowed us to rightsize many of our troubled loans. We believe that the worst is behind us, but we expect a few more quarters of uncertainty and choppiness in Commercial charge-offs and nonperforming loans.
Slide 12 outlines continuing uncertainties and our expected near-term trends. Capital One continues to show considerable resilience through the Great Recession and ongoing legislative and regulatory changes, but economic and regulatory uncertainties remain high. While the modest economic recovery continues, recent labor and housing market data shows stagnation and uncertainty. Foreclosure issues are further disrupting housing markets. As Gary discussed, uncertainty around reps and warranties remains elevated. Consumer demands remains weak, and the banking industry faces the development of hundreds of regulatory rules over the next couple of years to actually implement new laws and new capital standards. 
Our businesses and our business model are relatively less impacted by many aspects of the Dodd-Frank Act, as we are a "main street" bank rather than a Wall Street bank. Like all banks, we'll be subject to changing capital requirements that will evolve as U.S. and international regulators worked to coordinate the capital aspects of the Dodd-Frank Act and the ongoing Basel III discussions. As Gary discussed, we're well positioned for this emerging capital definitions and requirements. 
We've been able to absorb the existing and anticipated CARD Act impacts with our Domestic Card revenue margin and business model largely intact. Of course, there is ongoing regulatory uncertainty. But as long as the impact of regulatory changes promote and preserve a truly level playing field for all banks and consumer lenders, we believe that our underwriting and marketing capabilities, as well as our customer practices, will continue to be competitive advantages. 
Against that backdrop, our near-term expectations remained consistent with what we've articulated throughout the year. We expect that quarterly pre-provision earnings will decline heading into 2011. As I discussed earlier, we expect that the Domestic Card revenue margin will decline from its current level, as the factors keeping it elevated normalize over time. We also expect marketing expense will continue to ramp toward more normal level. We expect that loan balances will find a bottom over the next several quarters as charge-off continue to improve, the decline in runoff portfolios abate and seasonal patterns play out. We expect loan balances to stabilize and begin to grow modestly in 2011. As a result of these trends, we expect pre-provision earnings to stabilize in 2011.
I'll close tonight on Slide 13. One of the biggest issues facing the banking industry is how to grow and create value if there's an extended period of deleveraging and weak loan demand. It's easy to focus on the growth pressures caused by deleveraging, but deleveraging also create significant credit benefits and strong returns that help bridge the gap to a resumption of loan growth. 
We're well-positioned to pursue a broad set of growth opportunities even if consumer demand remains weak for an extended period of time. Many banks are reeling from the financial crisis and from poorly performing assets generated over the last decade. Others are struggling to address revenue and growth challenges, resulting from legislative and revelatory reform and the new level playing field they create. As a result, we're seeing opportunities to acquire businesses, assets portfolios and origination platform with attractive economics. 
Our balance sheet remains strong and resilient. We've weathered the recession relatively well, and our business are generating profits and capital. Credit losses are returning to more normal levels. We have a leading brand and advantage customer access across multiple channels, and we've invested to improve our infrastructure and expertise to support growth opportunities, like partnerships and acquisitions. We have a strong and flexible card infrastructure platform. 
We've added talent and created a deeper and more focused team to develop and manage our partnership strategy. We're building a scalable banking infrastructure, and we continuously deepen the talent and bench strength of our banking leadership team. Our investments are paying off. We've started new partnerships with Sony in the U.S. and Delta Air Lines in Canada. We expect to launch our partnership with Kohl's in early 2011, and we've completed the smooth and successful conversion to the Capital One Bank brand at our metro Washington, D.C. franchise. 
As consumer demand returns, we're well positioned to take share organically as  well. Our Domestic Card business is well positioned to take share on the new level playing field created by the CARD Act. We continue to drive winning product innovations, like the Venture card and Rewards Checking, and we've seen the return of loan growth begin in our repositioned Auto Finance business. We remain well positioned to take advantage of emerging opportunities and to deliver significant shareholder value over the long term. 
And now, Gary and I would be happy to answer your questions. Jeff?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had two questions, I'll ask them upfront. First one on the rep and warranty side, I appreciate the added disclosure. But I was wondering if we could get a greater breakdown of that $82 billion. I was wondering if we could get more color on the makeup, m
componenttext: I had two questions, I'll ask them upfront. First one on the rep and warranty side, I appreciate the added disclosure. But I was wondering if we could get a greater breakdown of that $82 billion. I was wondering if we could get more color on the makeup, maybe some details on the portfolio performance, as in the delinquency and charge-off rates you guys have experienced to date. And I don't know if you guys can give us specific reserves related to that, I know it's a small piece of the total, but I was wondering if we could get a specific number. And the second question is, just so I understand the U.S. Card revenue yield guidance, is it going to get to 15%, or is that not going to happen? And if it is going to get to the 15%, kind of when that would happen?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sanjay, it's Gary, let me take your question on the rep and warranty. And to the extent, we could give you a lot more detail on the $82 billion of, what we call, the everything-else category, I would. What I did say was that we believe, based on the analy
componenttext: Sanjay, it's Gary, let me take your question on the rep and warranty. And to the extent, we could give you a lot more detail on the $82 billion of, what we call, the everything-else category, I would. What I did say was that we believe, based on the analysis we've done -- and again, remember, we don't service a lot of these loans, so we don't have complete visibility into where these loans landed. But we believe that something around half ended up in unwrapped publicly issued private label securitizations. The other half have ended up perhaps in privately placed securitizations. They may have stayed as whole loans on the books of the original purchasers, where they may have been resold by those original purchasers, ones or many times over at various prices to other buyers, and so it is a more difficult universe to track. Certainly, we can make some broad assumptions about overall performance. But in order to comment to the reserve, we also need to take a look at a number of other factors that I described, and it would be hard to really break that down for you any more than we have.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sanjay, this is Rich. On the U.S. revenue margin, I know we've been continually pointing to 15%, and with a lot of confidence in our voice. And we seem to be having trouble getting there. The reason we went out, for a number of quarters now, pointing at 1
componenttext: Sanjay, this is Rich. On the U.S. revenue margin, I know we've been continually pointing to 15%, and with a lot of confidence in our voice. And we seem to be having trouble getting there. The reason we went out, for a number of quarters now, pointing at 15% is really it was trying to focus on the impact of the CARD Act, and the fact that we felt this kind of a -- that will take our revenue margin to 15%, which, strikingly, is kind of our equilibrium revenue margin we had before the Great Recession and all the legislation began. And the CARD Act has, in fact, played out very much as we would have expected, and so the underlying economics of our business as reflected in our 15% that we were targeting is very much as we expected. The revenue margin has continued to be buoyed by the better-than-expected credit and, to some extent, by the weakness in originations and fewer-than-expected teaser rates. So now that the CARD Act is most -- half quarter of the reasonable fees effect this quarter and the kind of the final effect now is to get the whole quarter of reasonable fees. We're kind of there with respect to the CARD Act effect, and we're probably going to get out of the business projecting revenue margins at this point. I would say though that the CARD Act -- so the Card business has very much the octane that we expected it to. The revenue margin, I think, will settle down off of its level right now because I think, at some point, we won't keep getting the boost from the fee and finance charge reserve effect. And at some point, growth is going to pick up, and that means more use of introductory rates and so on. The other impact that will start to happen on our Card revenue margin will be things like the Kohl's portfolio coming in. Pound-for-pound, the Kohl's portfolio actually lowers revenue margin and lowers charge-off rates as it is a very high-quality portfolio. So I think we're more really back into the equilibrium of a competitive environment that, I think, has a lot of opportunity for us to make good returns in the business. And I appreciate the spirit of the question.

componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Gary. As you know, we put the forth the suppression number. Think of that as your overall kind of equivalent when it comes to fees and finance charges. As the provision expense is for losses, the finance charge and fee reserves is going to be th
componenttext: Ken, it's Gary. As you know, we put the forth the suppression number. Think of that as your overall kind of equivalent when it comes to fees and finance charges. As the provision expense is for losses, the finance charge and fee reserves is going to be the equivalent, if you will, of the allowance. They both improved over the quarter, both the actual experience of recoveries and lower reversals, which would affect suppression as well as the finance charge and fee reserve. But we don't break that out. Surely, you can get some more color on that from the IR [Investor Relations] team over the course of the rest of the day.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: And then, separately, I understand you don't want to necessarily be in the business of projecting revenue margins going forward. But can you give us a little bit better clarity as to how much of the 15% -- at that point, how much would be promotional balances or how you thought the mix would look in the overall portfolio that got you to 15%?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in other words, Ken, you're saying -- honestly, our expectations that led us to the 15% were pretty darn modest origination levels. So this effect we're talking about that raised that sort of artificially raised revenue margins, this originations comin
componenttext: So in other words, Ken, you're saying -- honestly, our expectations that led us to the 15% were pretty darn modest origination levels. So this effect we're talking about that raised that sort of artificially raised revenue margins, this originations coming a little lower than expected, is a really small effect in the revenue margin conversation. The swamping effect that's going on here is the credit effect in making the number substantially bigger than 15%. There have been some other effects, frankly just some good dynamics in the Card business. Few things, where revenue itself, has just come in a little bit stronger, frankly, in the business than we had expected and as things turned slightly positive for us with respect to how the reasonable fee conversation came out. So there's some kind of, sustainably, a number of small effects on the sustainable business aspects of the revenue margin as well. But the big effect is credit, and that will continue to be the biggest noise factor one quarter to the next.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, almost all of the $82 billion would have come from GreenPoint more or less. Remember, we acquired them at the end of 2006, closed down the originations in the middle of 2007. And so just about all of those would have come from GreenPoint. The rest,
componenttext: Bill, almost all of the $82 billion would have come from GreenPoint more or less. Remember, we acquired them at the end of 2006, closed down the originations in the middle of 2007. And so just about all of those would have come from GreenPoint. The rest, to the extent there were any, would have been either Chevy Chase or our own origination platform. So that kind of gives you the breakdown of that.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Bill, yes, our subsidiary GreenPoint received one of the FHFA subpoenas. The subpoena seeks information on fewer than 2,000 GreenPoint mortgage loans that are part of some private label securitizations, in which Freddie Mac is an investor. We're in the process of collecting responsive documents.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I may, one follow-up. Is the probability, in your view of a put back on Alt-A loans, would you view that as lower versus other loans with more documentation? And just to kind of trying to get a sense on whether the put-back risk is lower there? And the
componenttext: If I may, one follow-up. Is the probability, in your view of a put back on Alt-A loans, would you view that as lower versus other loans with more documentation? And just to kind of trying to get a sense on whether the put-back risk is lower there? And then finally, I'm just trying to kind of try to get my arms around this probable and reasonably estimable threshold. I mean, basically, does that mean you have to see an increase in claim activity, to the extent that you start seeing bondholders organize, like the example that we see in the story today, in today's Wall Street Journal story about bondholders organizing, provides a good example of that. But that loan, those type of things wouldn't be sufficient to give rise to or provide a basis for you to build reserves, you'd actually have to see an increase in claim activity?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, with respect to your question about the Alt-A loans, look, I think in order to come up with a judgment about the risk, you need to take a look at multiple factors. Certainly, what the nature of the loan is may have an impact, but you have to take a
componenttext: Bill, with respect to your question about the Alt-A loans, look, I think in order to come up with a judgment about the risk, you need to take a look at multiple factors. Certainly, what the nature of the loan is may have an impact, but you have to take a look at a variety of other things. You've got to look at the loan underwriting quality, the actual losses on the loans. You'd have to take a look at the specific reps and warranties in the sales contracts, how they were assigned and so forth. So I think it would be wrong to believe that if you simply knew the nature of the structure of the loan that, that would somehow give you the decoder ring to figuring out where things go from there. And in terms of the actual actions on behalf of potential claimants, what I actually say is that the actual claims we received are not a particularly terribly accurate measure of risk because activity can show up in a bunch of different ways: discussions, file requests, litigation, saber rattling, all sorts of things. So I think it would be wrong to be able to point to any one item to identify what makes a claim and the potential loss, either probable and estimable. But no, there is no magic formula that something needs to get over a particular hurdle of activity in order to become probable and estimable. It can reach that stage beforehand, but there is a considerable amount of judgment that needs to be put into that.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Craig Maurer with CLSA.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Craig Maurer with CLSA.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, on the marketing spend. It was up materially this quarter. I was hoping to get your expectations for that, both in the coming quarter and over the next few years, whether or not you expect to get back to historical levels of marketing or how you're
componenttext: First, on the marketing spend. It was up materially this quarter. I was hoping to get your expectations for that, both in the coming quarter and over the next few years, whether or not you expect to get back to historical levels of marketing or how you're thinking about that budget. Number two, I know that this is a moving target, but if you could talk a little bit about how you're thinking about reserve methodology. Are you thinking about specific percentage of loans covering a specific level of forward-looking losses? Just a little bit of information on how that discussion is going internally.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, the way I would describe Capital One is very ready for business across pretty much everything that we used to do in the current business and a few new things. So it is really solely, at this point, a weak demand that is holding us back. I think unl
componenttext: Craig, the way I would describe Capital One is very ready for business across pretty much everything that we used to do in the current business and a few new things. So it is really solely, at this point, a weak demand that is holding us back. I think unlike a lot of players haven't really had to significantly redo and rebuild our business model in some of these parts of the Card business. So we are frustratingly, in a sense, ready for business. So demand has been pretty weak. It's not to say that it's not taking up because, in fact, in parts of the business, we can see more traction happening, and the fact that there's more marketing is a reflection that we see both actual and the prospect for more traction here. It is our expectation that marketing will go up in successive quarters. The fourth quarter has traditionally been a higher marketing level for us, just on a set of a seasonal basis with all of our sponsorship of bowls [bowl games] and different things. But if we look at the very good prospects we have to make money in the Card business under originations and that, combined with the weak demand, it's our expectation that originations are going to continue to increase quarter-over-quarter. And as that happens, partly as a leading indicator and partly following it, our marketing will continue to rise. It's still quite a bit lower level than the historical highs. But it's our expectation, we're going to return to pretty strong levels of marketing. But the demand needs to be there for that. We're not going to just go spend it, just ahead of the evidence in the demand.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Yes. Well, I was just trying to figure out how you're thinking about it. There's been question around whether banks are going to have to provide reserve for a specific amount of forward-looking losses or whether they'll be held to a bogey of total loans. I'm just curious about how you're thinking about it.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I mean that there has been a material change in that over the course of the quarter. Take a look, our charge-off rate fell 54 basis points in the quarter. Our allowance coverage ratio came down 46 basis points. The overall charge-off rate was
componenttext: Well, look, I mean that there has been a material change in that over the course of the quarter. Take a look, our charge-off rate fell 54 basis points in the quarter. Our allowance coverage ratio came down 46 basis points. The overall charge-off rate was 4.82% in the quarter, our coverage ratio of allowance to loans is 4.89%. I think by and large, we are reserving based on the trends that we observed. There's nothing in our allowance calculation that reflects any projected improvements in macroeconomic conditions going forward. As we move forward, provision levels will be based on the usual volumes, the actual credit performance and what we see kind of going forward. Certainly, we all know that FASB [Financial Accounting Standards Board] has out for exposure. It's draft on accounting for financial instruments, which would take people perhaps to a longer future view of losses. But at this point, most of our Consumer business is certainly in card. We go out for 12 months of loss in our Commercial business. It's well in excess of that. So we think we're in a reasonable place, and obviously, we'll have to see where the world goes in terms of any step changes that may occur in the future, based on changing accounting standards.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: And we'll go next to Bruce Harting with Barclays Capital.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have any comments on the changes happening in interchange? In other words, any special insights into merchant behavior with some of the pending changes if the Fed [Federal Reserves] were to lower debit interchange considerably. Any thoughts on earl
componenttext: Do you have any comments on the changes happening in interchange? In other words, any special insights into merchant behavior with some of the pending changes if the Fed [Federal Reserves] were to lower debit interchange considerably. Any thoughts on early indications for merchants steering customers between networks? I just like your insight on that, and maybe a comment on the Kohl's deal. Will that be the first of many? And are there any special attributes or features of that relationship, in terms of co-branding or things that you might want to talk about?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bruce, things are very early in terms of seeing actual indications of how merchants are going to change their behavior. I'm going to stick my neck out here a little bit. I would predict there may be less of an effect than some people imagine here. I guess
componenttext: Bruce, things are very early in terms of seeing actual indications of how merchants are going to change their behavior. I'm going to stick my neck out here a little bit. I would predict there may be less of an effect than some people imagine here. I guess I've been around this business for a long period of time. Plus, believe it or not, in a prior life, in my consulting days, I did extensive work in the gasoline retailing business, ironically, and the big thing everybody was studying was discount for cash and the big debate, what do you do about that and so on. And remember the phase everybody went through for discount for cash and then finally, it came back to -- the problem is, discount for cash sounded to consumers like surcharge for paying with a credit card, and there was a lot of consumer resistance to that. So look, I don't want to go too far out on a limb here but what I would say is that I just add this to one of the many kind of risk factors that we all have to keep an eye out over time. But I think the overall impact, I would still expect to be modest. However, I just want to point out, of course, the macro trend of the success of debit cards in gaining a lot of share against cash and checks and other things and, ultimately, on some metrics passing the credit card, I think it's a macro trend that will continue. And the Card business is going to face a lot of competition from alternatives here. But I think, overall, Bruce, it's not at the top of our risk factors but we're certainly going to keep an eye on that. With respect to Kohl's, let me just make a comment about partnership. If you look at partnerships and just kind of pull way back on partnerships, co-brand, private label, partnerships in the credit card space, they have ranged in the industry from being smashingly successful to very big duds. And so our conclusion on this thing is it's all about the partner, and it's all about the nature of the agreement with the partner. And it's all about the commitment that the partner has, what's the partner trying to really get out of one of these partnerships. So take Kohl's as an example, because I think Kohl's is a great example of a partnership where you have a very strong retailer. You have a very strong retailer who's very committed to their private label business, not as a way to "make a lot of money" but really as a way to build very deep loyalty. And they are very committed to their partnership with their card player. It's extremely important to Kohl's, and it's extremely important to them that they get a partner that's going to be equally committed to them. So this has all the makings of a very good deep relationship with the partner and the creation of positively selected credit on the private label partnership side. So all of that, that's a classic exhibit A of the kind of things that we're going for. Along the way, we look at a lot of partnerships. And we show up but don't make the bids because they kind of are at the end of the spectrum. So what you will see out of Capital One at a time when a number of credit card issuers are kind of struggling a little bit and where the companies that they have partnered with are looking for something a little different, we are moving into this space on a selective basis, and I think it's the right conclusion, Bruce, to expect us to be doing more of these over time. But again, it's going to be very selective.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, mostly normal, so it's going to be in the eye of the beholder. It feels like we're getting pretty close to some normal levels. Obviously, we have assessed far fewer fees. But as Rich said, we're pretty well through the implementation of t
componenttext: Well, obviously, mostly normal, so it's going to be in the eye of the beholder. It feels like we're getting pretty close to some normal levels. Obviously, we have assessed far fewer fees. But as Rich said, we're pretty well through the implementation of the CARD Act, so those levels are likely to normalize. The level of finance charges may rise or have risen a bit, but chances are those are also relatively close to normal. And then collectability feels like it's come back a lot closer than normal. Is there a little room for improvement? Probably. But certainly, it feels like we're closer to normal now than we have been, certainly if you look back, four to six quarters ago.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just kind of a clarification, you talked a little about the risk-weighted assets. How much of the risk-weighted assets from the consolidation of the securitization trusts are actually in RWA right now?
componenttext: And just kind of a clarification, you talked a little about the risk-weighted assets. How much of the risk-weighted assets from the consolidation of the securitization trusts are actually in RWA right now?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the RWA, or the risk-weighted assets, and people can see that on Slide 7, Moshe, that's probably the easiest place for me to give a very slight lesson here, looking back, so you can tell what's coming, going forward. So if you can see on Slide 7, since
componenttext: In the RWA, or the risk-weighted assets, and people can see that on Slide 7, Moshe, that's probably the easiest place for me to give a very slight lesson here, looking back, so you can tell what's coming, going forward. So if you can see on Slide 7, since the end of the fourth quarter, risk-weighted assets have gone up about $8 billion from $116 billion to $124 billion. We started out with about $48 billion of securitizations, and so you would think that about half of those, or $24 billion, would have to have been phased-in by this point in time. As it turns out, we had paid down almost that amount of securitization liabilities over the nine months, and so there was actually very little phase in of securitizations to do this quarter. And there has been, of course, shrinkage in -- but just because of the attrition and the runoff in some of the rest of our portfolio that's caused risk-weighted assets to go down. Looking forward, we have now two quarters to go until Q1 of '11 when we have to phase in the balance of the securitizations. It looks to us as though we paid down and so forth. We'll probably phase in something like $18 billion or $19 billion worth of securitizations between now and then. But I would be very surprised if the overall level of risk-weighted assets went up that much because, again, there are some natural attrition, both in the Card business and elsewhere in the portfolio. But I think the key thing to keep in mind is that because we had such a large amount of securitization paydown on our part over the course of the first three quarters of this year, you didn't see a big impact in the third quarter in terms of the on-boarding. You will see a more pronounced impact of the on-boarding of that last group of securitized assets in the first quarter of '11, which is why you see the projected view of regulatory ratios taking the path that they do on Slide 8.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Matthew Kelley with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Matthew Kelley with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just hoping you can give me an idea of which of your U.S. credit card has seen most consumer demand? What your consumers are looking for in this market?
componenttext: I'm just hoping you can give me an idea of which of your U.S. credit card has seen most consumer demand? What your consumers are looking for in this market?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matthew, that question is phrased from a product perspective. A lot of what we do is market similar-looking products to a lot of different segments. So I would say in terms of the major products, I mean, we have the Venture card. The Venture card is obvio
componenttext: Matthew, that question is phrased from a product perspective. A lot of what we do is market similar-looking products to a lot of different segments. So I would say in terms of the major products, I mean, we have the Venture card. The Venture card is obviously something that we advertise on TV to very differentiated product. We are comfortable with the traction that we're getting there, and we're very committed to that product offering and our continued, I think, successful efforts to penetrate the upper end of the transactor market. What we are doing is -- if we look at the marketplace, consistent with our strategy for the last 20 years, we tend to massively de-average the market and look for pockets of opportunities. And in some places, the market is at price levels that are not sustainable on a risk-adjusted basis, and we stay out of those. In other places, price levels and our own unique, I think, insights into this markets have led us to be very successful. So I kind of want to go back to -- let me synthesize a few of the questions and get back to, I think, that's a blend about a growth comment and a revenue margin comment, if I could. So I'd say just about every meeting that I have with the Card business, I can feel more traction than the meeting before. And we have a lot of tests that have been laid deep within the Great Recession that are starting to show insights about good business opportunities even in the context of, frankly, scared consumers and pretty dark times. And so we're finding more and more of the things that we've been testing were moving into rollout mode for. And I think that's why we feel a bullishness about our growth opportunities, and I think it will modestly show itself in the Card business. Of course, when you watch the Card business, that's also the segment, it has continued runoff of the Installment Loan business blended into the same thing. So you have to kind of keep that one in mind. So we feel very good about that and even at the same time while the partnership business opportunities are getting a lot of traction. Let me just make one more comment about the revenue margin. So the revenue margin, I mean, I think the credit effect has been the biggest thing that has cost this thing to be higher than 15%. But the net business, the way things have broken on the business side have been, on a positive side, outweighing the negative with respect to our revenue margin. I think it may take things like Kohl's, which comes in at a lot lower margin and a lot lower charge-offs, to actually get "normalized margin" down towards the kind of things that we pointed out, which is, I think, a reflection of the fact that, overall, there has been a -- the developments on margins have been slightly positive, I think, relative to our expectations. But where we see our business unfolding the amount of low-risk business that we think we're going to pick up, it probably gets you to the same place.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I can just ask one quick follow-up on one part of the implementation of the CARD Act I wanted to get your take on is the look-back feature on the repricing of loans. I just want to see how you guys think about that internally, and how much of
componenttext: And then if I can just ask one quick follow-up on one part of the implementation of the CARD Act I wanted to get your take on is the look-back feature on the repricing of loans. I just want to see how you guys think about that internally, and how much of an impact do you think that might be?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a requirement that market based -- well, the price increases, change in terms, based price increases imposed between the beginning of 2009 and February 21 of 2010, must compare pricing to similar accounts offered by the issuer to new applicants in
componenttext: There's a requirement that market based -- well, the price increases, change in terms, based price increases imposed between the beginning of 2009 and February 21 of 2010, must compare pricing to similar accounts offered by the issuer to new applicants in evaluating the appropriate price levels. In other words, the concept is they don't want you to have your repriced back book to be running at a level very different from that which is being offered to the front book, if you will, to new customers. And we've said for some time that we expect industry pricing to move higher after the CARD Act, and this is important for the health of new originations. But actually now, interestingly, with this particular requirement that's kind of the last aspect of the CARD Act interpretation, it becomes now doubly important. The price levels that issuers have for their new originations is kind of doubly important. Now we have done, as you can imagine, a lot of analysis at this. And when we compare segment of the back book versus a segment of the front book and how they are priced, we are comfortable that we're going to be in a good place with respect to this "unrepricing," if you will. There will be segments of the business that we do some unrepricing. But frankly, dynamically, we do that all the time. So I think that this is an important issue the industry is going to have to come to terms with. We've been all over this at Capital One. And frankly, because we are so focused on making sure in a world where repricing is a lot more constrained than it was before, as you've been hearing me say, Matthew, for a long time, it is very important that we underwrite the originations originally at price levels that are sustainable through the long term. And therefore, it's not surprising at Capital One that those price levels would be consistent with how the back book is priced, because it's really underwritten on the very same credit foundation.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Chris Brendler with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Chris Brendler with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow-up on that question on the consumer. And historically, you guys have not been a heavy user of teaser rates but some data out there suggests that you are leaning more towards teaser rates. It seems though, from the industry that I've
componenttext: I just want to follow-up on that question on the consumer. And historically, you guys have not been a heavy user of teaser rates but some data out there suggests that you are leaning more towards teaser rates. It seems though, from the industry that I've seen, that consumers seem to be a little more turned off of teaser rate activity. We've seen a lot more mail this year but not a lot of growth in the cash volumes at Visa and MasterCard. Is that true? Are consumers less responsive to teaser rates than they have been in the past? Has there been a psychological change in the way that consumers view the teaser rate offers?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I have several things to say, Chris. First of all, when you said that it seems that you're doing quite a bit more teasers than you were before, I just want to clarify something that Moshe put out a report on. And Moshe was very correctly reading the da
componenttext: So I have several things to say, Chris. First of all, when you said that it seems that you're doing quite a bit more teasers than you were before, I just want to clarify something that Moshe put out a report on. And Moshe was very correctly reading the data from the source he was getting, it was not an accurate reflection of Capital One. So let me actually just ground that for a second. It looked like Capital One was doing a dramatically increased amount of 0% balance transfer teasers. Moshe, when we saw your analysis, we went back and looked at the underlying data and so on. And I'm not sure what happened with respect to the source data, but we are not doing a lot of 0% balance transfer teasers. So I just wanted to clarify that. We, like the industry, does, for a certain segment, do 0% purchase teasers. So having clarified that, let me talk about teasers. I think teasers are something that is going to be with the card industry as a permanent fixture here. And in fact, teasers have been very explicitly allowed in all of the legislative and regulatory work as well. I think it's no different from sales at Bloomingdale's. It's just kind of how the business works, I think it will. So I don't think consumers are really turned off by teasers. I just think consumers are not buying a lot of credit card products right now. I think the other thing with teasers right now is that the teaser rates in an environment of very low interest rates are not nearly as costly for the card issuer. So I've been predicting for some time, you're going to see teaser rates as sort of a fixture of the Card business. What I've also said though is, for those of you who analyze the business, judge it not by it's 0% teasers, the purchase teasers, in particular, because rates are low right now and those, by definition, have limited time period. Judge it by the go-to rates, that is really the key. And when we look at what happened with respect to go-to rates -- I've been talking to you in virtually every call about the trend in pricing out there, so we can keep an eye on. Is the industry in a world where there's a lot less flexibility to do repricing? Is the industry building in appropriate margins here? And the good news is that if you look at, let's call it, go-to rate minus prime to sort of adjust for what's happened in the interest rate, that has gone up. Although it sort of stabilized now, but it's gone up about 200 basis points since basically the CARD Act was passed. However, I think the industry has done it the easy way, because they basically have kept pricing where it is while interest rates have gone down. So I'm not as confident that the industry is as robust in their pricing as they need to be when things go up. You had another question there, Chris?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The related question is you've talked about consumer demand still being weak. You're seeing a little bit of a pickup, it sounds like. Any thoughts or commentary by segment? Are you seeing any better signs of demand at the low end of the market? Or convers
componenttext: The related question is you've talked about consumer demand still being weak. You're seeing a little bit of a pickup, it sounds like. Any thoughts or commentary by segment? Are you seeing any better signs of demand at the low end of the market? Or conversely, in the high end, where it's so competitive for those high spenders, are you seeing a pickup there as well?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that the pickup we're seeing is modest, and this is modest with a small M. It's not a dramatic thing, but the sign is very important to us. The modest pickup we're seeing in most of the segments, frankly, that we compete in, from the higher end do
componenttext: I think that the pickup we're seeing is modest, and this is modest with a small M. It's not a dramatic thing, but the sign is very important to us. The modest pickup we're seeing in most of the segments, frankly, that we compete in, from the higher end down lower. So it's a small effect. I wouldn't take it all the way to the bank. But it matters a lot to us because we are really ready for business and, I think, have a lot of opportunity to have a very attractive return originations.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: And your last question comes from John Stilmar with SunTrust.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, just wanted to put a finer point on your foray into private label. You've always been quote, as you've referenced, de-averaging the market for many years now and sort of going into the little nooks and kernels of the U.S. consumer market. So I guess
componenttext: Rich, just wanted to put a finer point on your foray into private label. You've always been quote, as you've referenced, de-averaging the market for many years now and sort of going into the little nooks and kernels of the U.S. consumer market. So I guess, I find the move into what seems to be a little bit more of a commoditized product or auction process a little more interesting. What am I missing about that market that's different today? And how can Capital One, given its knitting [ph]? Why is that market so attractive?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a very smart question, John, because we're -- companies that always go where auctions are held tend not end up at the top of the performance list. So that's kind of a core principle of ours. So let me make one structural point and one cyclical poin
componenttext: That's a very smart question, John, because we're -- companies that always go where auctions are held tend not end up at the top of the performance list. So that's kind of a core principle of ours. So let me make one structural point and one cyclical point. Let me start with the cyclical point. The auctions are happening, but let's put it this way, the pricing is radically different. I mean, we're talking about pricing that is, in some cases, in terms of premiums, a fraction of what it was a couple of years ago for the same portfolios that turned some years ago. So I'm okay with auctions, if I understand the nature of what part of the cycle I'm playing in, and so there's a cyclical effect here. The structural thing I want to talk about is, kind of goes back to that point that some private label businesses are actually really attractive. And I think, for us, there's a bit of a diversification benefit that also comes in a world where there's uncertainty about interchange, uncertainty about certain of some of the core ways that business has been done in the past, I think. That although it's not our primary motivation, I think there are benefits also just from sort of diversification that comes in the world of interchange risk. But primarily, what we have done is really -- what we're trying to do is take advantage of adversity, and the great adversity we all can seize here is the Great Recession. The Great Recession not only has changed supply and demand, but it allowed us to get a phenomenal window into how credit risk works, and so we try to be real students on how credit risk and positive and negative selection of work in every part of the market. And we're really on the hunt for the, shall we say, more positively selected partnership programs.

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question, Gary, with regards to the Consumer Banking segment. Is this really a 13% revenue margin business? Then clearly, there's the positive mix that is influenced there given the Auto is becoming a more dominant part of this. But
componenttext: And then my follow-up question, Gary, with regards to the Consumer Banking segment. Is this really a 13% revenue margin business? Then clearly, there's the positive mix that is influenced there given the Auto is becoming a more dominant part of this. But can you help lay out for me what we should start expecting for the segment as it kind of moves through time into 2011?

headline: Capital One Financial Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I don't want to go into great detail. I wouldn't read much into any given quarter. Remember, in the Consumer segment, we have: our Home Loans segment and a lot of that. The back book is going to be moving quite a bit up and down; Auto is, we've
componenttext: Yes, John, I don't want to go into great detail. I wouldn't read much into any given quarter. Remember, in the Consumer segment, we have: our Home Loans segment and a lot of that. The back book is going to be moving quite a bit up and down; Auto is, we've indicated, we're seeing some positive growth there, at this point, overall. But I think it's premature to try to identify what the long-run destination of that particular segment is, and again it does reflect a lot of different businesses. And so if you take a look actually over the last couple of quarters, we've seen a lot of a puts and takes, and I think we'll see some movements for a while. But I wouldn't read any long-term trends into that, but we'll be talking to you about that over the next period of time.
